item.title: Remove
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[code] public String censorString(String text) {
String[] censor = { playerPass, “bitch”, " ass ", “whore”, “hoe”, “fag”, “**", “fuck”, “f u c k”, “slut”, “shit”, “no-ip”, “servergame”, “no - ip”, “jagex”, “runescape”, "”, “dick”, “pussy”, “skank”, “bastard”, “cock”, “**", “beaner”, “beener”, “this server sucks”, “nigga”, “negro”, “cracka”, “honkey”, “homo”, “porn”, “wet back”, “chink” };
text = text.toLowerCase();
for (int x = 0; x < censor.length; x++) {
if (text.contains(censor[x])) {
text = text.replaceAll(censor[x], "”);
}
}
text = Character.toUpperCase(text.charAt(0)) + text.substring(1);
return text;
}

public void yell(String msg) {
    String text = msg;
    if (msg.startsWith("@")) {
        text = Character.toUpperCase(text.charAt(5)) + text.substring(6);
    } else {
        text = Character.toUpperCase(text.charAt(0)) + text.substring(1);
    }
    server.playerHandler.messageToAll = text;
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Remove
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:9, topic:386141”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=481895.msg3529143#msg3529143 date=1300038410]
so. if i do something like this:
yell(playerName + ": " + color[0] + “” + censorString(text));
yell(playerName + ": " + color[1] + “” + censorString(text));
yell(playerName + ": " + color[2] + “” + censorString(text));

The [0] is player rights 0 and will call @dre@ <=WOW WTH HAPPEN HERE!!
The [1] is player rights 1 and will call @or2@
The [2] is player rights 2 and will call @red@

Right? or am i wayy off?
[/quote]
Instead of changing the rights it changes the color of it… but how do i make it specified by the rights of the person?[/quote]
That’s how it is… You don’t even have to expand the code into multipe yell statements…

String color[] = { "@dre@", "@or2@", "@red@", "@mag@", "@dre@" };

I’m not going to go again on which Element calls which color. You just switch them around…
You need to read the tutorial about switch statements.

Read full topic

item.title: Remove
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

You just switch the items in the array around. You should look up arrays at the Oracle Java tutorials.

Anyway, how that works is, it will check your playerRights each time the method is called and it gets to your yell method. For example, if your playerRights was to be 3, this code

yell(playerName + ": " + color[playerRights] + "" + censorString(text));

Would be like this:

yell(playerName + ": " + color[3] + "" + censorString(text));

This is obviously important because the number states which array element it will replace with the color variable. Now, an array’s indices start at 0, which means that “color[0]” will call “@dre@”, “color[1]” will call “@or2@”, “color[2]” will call “@red@”, “color[3]” will call “@mag@”, and “color[4]” will call “@dre@”.

Now, if we were to want to change that, we’ll have to look back on our color[] declaration…

String color[] = { "@dre@", "@or2@", "@red@", "@mag@", "@dre@" };

Again, the element at index 0 calls dre, the element at index 1 calls or2, the element at index 2 calls red, the element at index 3 calls mag and the element at index 4 calls dre. That means admins will have their text come out red. Now depending on what colors you want to use, you’d replace @red@ with the color you want. Save, compile and test.
Edit: failed with code tags…

Read full topic
